subject: parse_registry: make the script more flexible

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 49aa131f718000ddd5fce833487f72b14990aa04

Why?  parse_registries is meant to be run to update all registries published from dmtf;  Selectively running it might mean that we get one version of one registry, and a different version of another, which we don't want, and defeats some of the intent of automating this.

Please add a little more details on what you're trying to accomplish here.

Say I am only interested in making changes to Privilege registry and its script during development, the current script doesn't allow us do so. For example, one day we have 10 schemas, I don't want to regenerate every schema during every iteration of the development. Is that a fair requirement?

Yes, I can make "all" by default.

> Say I am only interested in making changes to Privilege registry and its script during development,

I read your commit message, and I'm still not really sure why this is helpful.  Part of the intent of what we have is that running the tool should produce the same reproducible output every time, so even if you only care about privilege registry, generating the rest of the files should have no effect, and the actual generation takes a trivial amount of time.

There's something I'm missing here, but I'm not sure what it is.

My worry here is that folks see these command line options, and start running just the registry they care about when a new version comes out, instead of updating us to the complete Redfish pack.  Updating everything is the intent of the script, to keep us consistent to released versions.  This partial update has happened in the past, so this isn't hypothetical.  In theory, the CI would catch that, but it's not perfect.
So, if one updates the version in the script but not pass a full list when they manually update the sources, CI will catch that.

Lets start with "why is this behavior useful" then we can back up to "how do we meet both needs".

Yes, CI _might_ catch it, but it's imperfect, and there have been times we've had to disable it.  Also, having a tool with options that are effectively "illegal" if you run, and having it catch in CI isn't a good developer experience.

The reason has been answered. For faster development of this script. Ideally we should modularize this script and unit test it, such that I won't care line 47 to line 140 at all when modifying line 141 and below. That's not supported today. This patch I did at least allows me to only generate privilege register. You've said there might be one day there are 10+ registries. Being able to update one of them probably can save more time at that time. 

I heard your opinion and agreed by default all should be updated at once.

> For faster development of this script.

This is what I'm not understanding.  The generation takes almost no time to run, so why is it faster?

> Ideally we should modularize this script and unit test it

This is a different discussion about how complex we want this script to become.  It's a compile-time-run tool that generates a static c++ file;  In terms of priorities, unit testing this script is pretty low on my list.

> such that I won't care line 47 to line 140 at all when modifying line 141

If you haven't modified line 47 to line 140, why, in the current model that just does everything do you have to worry about it today?


> can save more time at that time. 

I don't understand what time we're saving here, can you be more specific?  Is it runtime of the script each time you make an edit? Generating each registry is an imperceptible amount of time compared to the HTTP GET to get the zip and unzip it, so that doesn't really track for me.

```
[hi on] nanzhou@nanzhou:~/Desktop/bmcweb$ time scripts/parse_registries.py 

real    0m1.493s
user    0m0.401s
sys     0m0.046s
[hi on] nanzhou@nanzhou:~/Desktop/bmcweb$ time scripts/parse_registries.py --registries privilege

real    0m0.667s
user    0m0.213s
sys     0m0.030s
```

Right.. I understand the absolute time spent is small. Just this comes to my mind that being able to update a single part of the whole registries is good to have. Thus I spent 10 minutes or so to develop a main function for this script. It shows it cuts more than 50% of the time.

Now I spent more then 10 minutes to convince you this is good, which is not something I really want to do. 😊 

I don't quite understand the downside: you worry about people misunderstood the arguments? Can I just add a comment to this script to say when submitting final changes, run with the full list?

> ```
> [hi on] nanzhou@nanzhou:~/Desktop/bmcweb$ time scripts/parse_registries.py 
> 
> real    0m1.493s
> user    0m0.401s
> sys     0m0.046s
> [hi on] nanzhou@nanzhou:~/Desktop/bmcweb$ time scripts/parse_registries.py --registries privilege
> 
> real    0m0.667s
> user    0m0.213s
> sys     0m0.030s
> ```
> 

Ok, that's what I was missing.  1.5 seconds to 600s matters to you, which is pretty different compared to myself, where those two are essentially equivalent as far as I'm concerned.

> Right.. I understand the absolute time spent is small. Just this comes to my mind that being able to update a single part of the whole registries is good to have. Thus I spent 10 minutes or so to develop a main function for this script. It shows it cuts more than 50% of the time.

50% of something already very small, but now I understand, it's just a case of:
https://xkcd.com/1205/

I think i understand what you're getting at, and it's fine.

> 
> Now I spent more then 10 minutes to convince you this is good, which is not something I really want to do. 😊 

Ideally this "why" of "it drops the script runtime from 1.5 seconds to 600ms, and that helps my workflow" would've been in the commit message originally 😊

> 
> I don't quite understand the downside: you worry about people misunderstood the arguments?

I'm worried about people expecting that they can send in a code review that only updates one portion of the registry pack.  That's fine, we'll deal with it when and if the issue arises.

> Can I just add a comment to this script to say when submitting final changes, run with the full list?

I don't even think that's needed in this case.  If it's a problem, we'll remove the parser later.

Thanks for indulging me.

> Ideally this "why" of "it drops the script runtime from 1.5 seconds to 600ms, and that helps my workflow" would've been in the commit message originally 😊

Done. Added. 👍
Could we default it to all? I.e. if you run it like it was before, it is the same behavior
I don't have strong opinion. IMO it's not a big deal to just add "--all". I am not aware of any automation script that we need to change.

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/run-ci#L7

Would need to change for sure.  I'm not really sure how this passed CI (maybe it's not returning the correct exit codes on bad input?)

I'm with gunnar, defaults here should be to just do everything, because that's the most common operation.  I'd still like to understand why anyone would want to do anything OTHER than all, but lets follow up on the other thread.

Oh, I don't know we have that hooked up. I see now https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc-build-scripts/blob/82aaba037aa922a6aa0e118f8cc04531becc42cd/scripts/unit-test.py#L1255

Yes, I can make all by default.
Can you please check and understand how CI was able to pass with the change prior?  Is argument parser not setting a return code on command failures?

> Can you please check and understand how CI was able to pass with the change prior?

Patch set 1?

The previous script does nothing if no arguments are given, thus no diff, thus no CI error.

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/run-ci#L9

> > Can you please check and understand how CI was able to pass with the change prior?
> 
> Patch set 1?
> 
> The previous script does nothing if no arguments are given, thus no diff, thus no CI error.

Right, and the "do nothing" is I think the problem on that patchset, because it does nothing without setting a return code.  With that said, now that the default is to do the old behavior, I think we're ok.

> 
> https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/run-ci#L9

If this goes forward, Could we just make this a list of registries?  Or some kind of parser that allows multiple inputs without having to have each one in-turn.  I'm not sure having each registry have its own -- argument scales beyond the 3 we have today, and I think redfish and swordfish have ~10 potential ones we could add.
Done. See what I have now. It's a list.
Pretty sure we want default=True on everything.  Just running the script with no args should do the old behavior.
This part was not needed and removed
